BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. First half of night: Rapid increase in avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular along the border with France heavy snowfall above approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind a large number of dry avalanches are possible from the second half of the night, even very large ones. In the typical avalanche paths in particular in the regions with a lot of snow they can reach as far as the valley bottom.
As the snowfall level rises moist and wet avalanches are possible at any time, in particular medium-sized ones.
As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, large wind slabs formed above the tree line. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep north, east and south facing slopes. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. The conditions are dangerous for ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area there is more snow than usual.
10 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m. The sleet gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack below approximately 2300 m.
The rain will give rise during the night to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2200 m.
Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on steep, little used shady slopes. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Tuesday: The weather will be mild. During the day: Up to the tree line rain will fall. New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger, especially along the border with France. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist snow slides and avalanches being released will increase further. Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs are very prone to triggering in all aspects. Caution is to be exercised in particular above approximately 2200 m, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Avalanches can be released easily and reach medium size. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack serve as an alarm indicating the danger. Remotely triggered and natural avalanches are possible in isolated cases.

There is a danger of gliding avalanches and moist snow slides. This applies on steep slopes below approximately 2400 m. In the course of the day the activity of gliding avalanches will increase.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep slopes above approximately 2200 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 15 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 2000 m. As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force westerly wind, extensive wind slabs will form. These are lying on soft layers in all aspects at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2200 m. The rain will give rise to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. First half of night: Rapid increase in avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 4 (high) intensive snowfall above approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind dry avalanches are possible from the second half of the night, even very large ones in isolated cases. In the typical avalanche paths in particular in the regions with a lot of snow they can reach as far as the valley bottom.
As the snowfall level rises moist and wet avalanches are possible at any time, in particular medium-sized ones.
As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, large wind slabs formed above the tree line. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep north, east and south facing slopes. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. The conditions are sometimes critical for ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m. The sleet gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack below approximately 2300 m.
The rain will give rise during the night to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2200 m.
Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on steep, little used shady slopes. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Tuesday: The weather will be mild. During the day: Up to the tree line rain will fall. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist snow slides and avalanches being released will increase further. Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger. The danger of moist and wet avalanches is close to the boundary with danger level 4 (high).
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In the last few days sometimes large wind slabs formed in all aspects. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches. In some places avalanches can also penetrate down to the ground and reach large size in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase gradually. In the event of rain this applies in particular.
The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of sharply rising temperatures and rain up to high altitudes the snowpack can not consolidate. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in particular on northwest to east to south facing aspects. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, depending on the infuence of the wind. Below the tree line only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist snow slides and avalanches being released will increase further. Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger, especially along the border with France. In the evening as a consequence of the rain there will be an increase in the avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In the last few days sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed on north, east and southeast facing slopes. These are to be avoided above approximately 2300 m. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches in some places, including medium-sized ones. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Wet avalanches during the day are possible. They can also be triggered in the old snowpack and reach quite a large size. The current avalanche situation calls for defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of sharply rising temperatures and rain up to high altitudes the snowpack can not consolidate. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in particular on northwest to east to south facing aspects. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, depending on the infuence of the wind. Below the tree line only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist snow slides and avalanches being released will increase further. Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger, especially along the border with France. In the evening as a consequence of the rain there will be an increase in the avalanche danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In the last few days sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed on north, east and southeast facing slopes. These are to be avoided above approximately 2300 m. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches in some places, including medium-sized ones. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Wet avalanches during the day are possible. They can also be triggered in the old snowpack and reach quite a large size. The current avalanche situation calls for defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of sharply rising temperatures and rain up to high altitudes the snowpack can not consolidate. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in particular on northwest to east to south facing aspects. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, depending on the infuence of the wind. Below the tree line only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist snow slides and avalanches being released will increase further. Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Moist and wet avalanches are possible during the course of the night, but they will be mostly small.
As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, sometimes deep wind slabs formed at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on very steep north, east and south facing slopes. In particular in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Careful route selection is advisable.
Wet avalanches during the day are likely to occur even now.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones only a little snow is now lying. The snowpack is largely stable and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong crust. The avalanche prone locations are rare.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will not decrease for the time being.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Until the afternoon the wind will be moderate to strong. The fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The fresh wind slabs can be released easily by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence above approximately 2200 m.
Above approximately 2000 m small to medium-sized moist avalanches are possible. Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The strong wind has transported the loosely bonded old snow. The wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and generally at high altitudes. Wind slabs are in some cases small but can be released easily. Avalanche prone weak layers exist in the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs are prone to triggering in particular on northwest to north to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2200 m. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized and can be released even by a single winter sport participant. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.

On steep slopes small to medium-sized gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow will fall. As a consequence of the strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. This applies especially in the regions with a lot of snow. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
The rain will give rise to softening of the snowpack in some cases at low and intermediate altitudes.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. The weather conditions will foster a gradual settling of the snow drift accumulations.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger, especially along the border with France. As the day progresses as a consequence of warming there will be only a slight increase in the danger of dry and moist avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In the last few days sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in high Alpine regions. The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can still be released in some cases especially on north to east to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are to be avoided in particular in very steep terrain.
In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
Slight increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying. Below approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack is largely stable and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust. Towards its base, the snowpack is moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist snow slides and avalanches being released will increase a little.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering above approximately 2400 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. The old snowpack is largely stable. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust below approximately 2600 m. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.

From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will cause a gradual settling of the snow drift accumulations.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The mostly small wind slabs of the last few days can be released in isolated cases on extremely steep shady slopes and generally in high Alpine regions. In particular in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised as well in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls. As the snowfall level rises wet loose snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones only a little snow is now lying. The snowpack is largely stable and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong crust. The avalanche prone locations are rare.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist snow slides and avalanches being released will increase further. Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow is lying on surface hoar in particular on wind-protected shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs of yesterday can be released by a single winter sport participant especially on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in north to northeast to northwest facing aspects and on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of low temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack consolidated. The snowpack remains unfavourable in particular on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanches can in isolated cases be released, in particular by large loads. This applies in particular on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes, and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. Wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Some snow will fall in some regions. Wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and at elevated altitudes. They are mostly small.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs above approximately 1800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche conditions are mostly favourable. Isolated small avalanches are possible in isolated cases. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will become generally stable. Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls mostly small wind slabs formed.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads,.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in the high Alpine regions. Wind slabs are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind will transport only a little snow. The wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines and generally at high altitudes. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are shallow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be generally stable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow is lying on top of a quite favourable old snowpack in all aspects above approximately 400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack is fairly homogeneous and has a loosely bonded surface.
